answerOptions.text: The cafe is expanding to serve breakfast only.
answerOptions.rationale: There's no mention of breakfast services.

answerOptions.text: Health inspectors shut the cafe down at noon daily.
answerOptions.rationale: No evidence of health code actions; the changes are operational choices.

questions.passage: The library added power strips to every long table and posted 'Quiet Study Area' signs. The tables fill quickly with students using laptops and notebooks.
questions.question: What inference is most reasonable?

answerOptions.text: Demand for quiet study space with access to power has increased.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The added power strips and full tables indicate growing need for powered study areas.

answerOptions.text: The library plans to remove all books.
answerOptions.rationale: Nothing suggests eliminating books; changes relate to study space.

answerOptions.text: Students are forbidden from bringing laptops.
answerOptions.rationale: The power strips encourage laptop use, not forbid it.

answerOptions.text: The library is closing the study area soon.
answerOptions.rationale: Investments in power strips and signage suggest continued use, not closure.

questions.passage: An email from the property manager reads: 'We will be entering apartments between 9 a.m. and noon on Tuesday to replace air filters. You do not need to be home.'
questions.question: Which inference is best supported by the email?

answerOptions.text: The management has keys and permission to access units for maintenance.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Routine entry without tenants present implies access and lease-based permission for maintenance.

answerOptions.text: Tenants must replace their own air filters.
answerOptions.rationale: The email says management will replace them.

answerOptions.text: Apartments will be inspected for lease violations.
answerOptions.rationale: The purpose specified is filter replacement, not inspections.

answerOptions.text: Only empty apartments will be serviced.
answerOptions.rationale: The message refers to occupied units; tenants need not be home.

questions.passage: The community garden's raised beds are overgrown with weeds. A watering schedule is posted on the gate, but most slots are blank. The latest newsletter says, 'We are seeking additional volunteers for upkeep.'
questions.question: Which inference is most supported by these details?

answerOptions.text: Volunteer participation has declined, leading to maintenance issues.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Overgrowth, empty schedule slots, and a call for volunteers indicate insufficient participation.

answerOptions.text: The garden is switching to artificial turf.
answerOptions.rationale: No evidence suggests replacing the garden beds.

answerOptions.text: A pest destroyed all the plants overnight.
answerOptions.rationale: Weeds and lack of watering, not pest damage, are emphasized.

answerOptions.text: The garden is thriving and fully staffed.
answerOptions.rationale: The conditions described suggest the opposite.

topics.title: Advanced Analysis of Tone and Purpose

quizzes.title: Advanced Analysis of Tone and Purpose

questions.passage: The room was a disaster. Clothes were thrown on every chair, dirty dishes were piled on the desk, and the bed was unmade. His mother stood in the doorway, hands on her hips, and said, 'This room isn't going to clean itself.'
questions.question: What can be inferred from the mother's statement?

answerOptions.text: She is offering to clean the room for him.
answerOptions.rationale: Her statement and posture imply she expects him to clean it, not that she will.

answerOptions.text: She is telling him that he needs to clean his room.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Her statement is an indirect command, a common way for a parent to tell a child to do a chore.

answerOptions.text: She believes the room will magically become clean.
answerOptions.rationale: Her statement is literal, but her meaning is the opposite.

answerOptions.text: She is impressed by how messy the room is.
answerOptions.rationale: Her posture (hands on hips) and her statement suggest disapproval, not admiration.

questions.passage: The candidate's speech was a masterclass in ambiguity. He promised 'prosperity for all' without detailing any economic policies. He vowed to 'strengthen our communities' without mentioning a single specific program. He spoke of 'a brighter future' but offered no roadmap to get there. He left the stage to thunderous applause.
questions.question: What is the author's tone toward the candidate?

answerOptions.text: Admiring and supportive
answerOptions.rationale: The author is pointing out the lack of substance, which is a criticism.

answerOptions.text: Critical and skeptical
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. By repeatedly highlighting the contrast between the candidate's vague, positive promises and the complete lack of specific plans, the author is expressing skepticism and a critical view of the candidate's style.

answerOptions.text: Neutral and objective
answerOptions.rationale: The repeated pattern of 'promised X without detailing Y' is a clear rhetorical choice to create a critical tone, not a neutral one.

answerOptions.text: Confused and puzzled
answerOptions.rationale: The author is not confused they are making a clear point about the candidate's lack of substance.

questions.passage: It is often said that a journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step. This is a comforting thought, but it is also a misleading one. It implies a smooth, linear progression. In my experience, the journey is less of a straight road and more of a dense, tangled forest. The first step is easy it is the hundredth, when you are lost and exhausted, that truly tests your resolve. It is the moment you decide to take the hundred-and-first step, and not the first, that defines the journey.
questions.question: What is the author's primary purpose in this passage?

answerOptions.text: To agree with and explain the traditional proverb.
answerOptions.rationale: The author explicitly calls the proverb 'misleading' and argues against it.

answerOptions.text: To offer a more realistic and challenging perspective on the nature of long journeys, emphasizing perseverance over initiation.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The author's purpose is to critique the simplicity of the original proverb and to propose a new, more realistic metaphor that values resilience in the middle of the struggle over the simple act of starting.

answerOptions.text: To tell a story about a time they were lost in a forest.
answerOptions.rationale: The 'forest' is used as a metaphor for a difficult journey, not a literal story.

answerOptions.text: To persuade the reader never to start a long journey.
answerOptions.rationale: The author is not discouraging journeys, but rather trying to give a more honest perspective on what they require.

questions.passage: By mid-morning, half the office wore sweaters and wrapped their hands around hot mugs. Two emails asked if facilities could 'bump the temperature up a bit.'
questions.question: What is the most reasonable inference about the office environment?

answerOptions.text: It is colder than employees find comfortable.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Sweaters, hot drinks, and requests to increase the temperature suggest the office is too cold.

answerOptions.text: The air conditioning is completely broken.
answerOptions.rationale: There's no evidence of a total failure, only that it's set too low.

answerOptions.text: The building has no heating system.
answerOptions.rationale: Requests to change the temperature imply a working system.

answerOptions.text: Everyone is sick with a cold.
answerOptions.rationale: The behavior is about temperature, not illness.

questions.passage: When the first drops fell, everyone in line moved under the bus shelter. A moment later, the sound of steady drumming filled the sidewalk.
questions.question: What can you infer about the weather?

answerOptions.text: It started raining.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. People moved under shelter, and the 'steady drumming' suggests rain.

answerOptions.text: It started snowing.
answerOptions.rationale: Snow does not typically create a 'steady drumming' on sidewalks and shelters.

answerOptions.text: The wind stopped completely.
answerOptions.rationale: Wind is not mentioned as changing.

answerOptions.text: The temperature rose sharply.
answerOptions.rationale: No temperature change is described.

questions.passage: A press release announced a 'strategic realignment' and 'operational efficiencies.' The next day, dozens of employees posted that they had been laid off. The company's stock price rose 6% by market close.
questions.question: Which inference best explains the market reaction?

answerOptions.text: Investors expect cost-cutting layoffs to improve short-term profits.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Euphemistic language plus layoffs and a stock jump indicate anticipated profitability due to reduced expenses.

answerOptions.text: Investors assume the company hired more staff.
answerOptions.rationale: The posts indicate layoffs, not hiring.

answerOptions.text: The company announced a new product launch.
answerOptions.rationale: No product is mentioned; only restructuring.

answerOptions.text: Stock prices always rise after press releases.
answerOptions.rationale: Market reactions vary; the details here point to cost-cutting as the cause.

questions.passage: At the farmer's market, one stall sold tomatoes in identical plastic clamshells with barcodes. A sign read 'Farm Fresh!' The vendor wore a shirt with a regional distributor's logo.
questions.question: What is the best-supported inference about the tomatoes?

answerOptions.text: They were likely purchased from a distributor, not grown by the vendor.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Barcoded clamshells and the distributor logo suggest resale rather than direct-from-farm produce.

answerOptions.text: They are guaranteed organic.
answerOptions.rationale: No evidence of organic certification is provided.

answerOptions.text: They were picked that morning from a nearby field.
answerOptions.rationale: Packaging and barcodes make this less likely.

answerOptions.text: They are imported from overseas.
answerOptions.rationale: The passage does not specify origin beyond the distributor clue.

questions.passage: A sign on the library door reads: 'Closed 1–4 p.m. for staff training. Reopens at 4 p.m.' Several patrons check their watches and say they'll come back later.
questions.question: What can you infer about the library's hours today?

answerOptions.text: It will reopen after 4 p.m.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The sign explicitly states the reopening time.

answerOptions.text: It is closed all day.
answerOptions.rationale: The sign indicates a temporary closure only.

answerOptions.text: It opens for the first time at 4 p.m.
answerOptions.rationale: The library is already operating but temporarily closed for training.

answerOptions.text: It will not open again this week.
answerOptions.rationale: Nothing in the sign suggests a multi-day closure.

questions.passage: The city's budget reduced funding for parks maintenance by 20% this year. Neighbors have posted photos of overgrown fields and overflowing trash bins. A council member proposed a 'Friends of the Parks' volunteer program to help with upkeep.
questions.question: What is the best-supported conclusion?

answerOptions.text: Reduced maintenance funding has led to visible decline, prompting efforts to fill the gap with volunteers.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The sequence of cuts, visible problems, and a volunteer proposal supports this conclusion.

answerOptions.text: The parks department secretly increased staff.
answerOptions.rationale: Evidence shows reduced funding and deterioration, not expansion.

answerOptions.text: Trash increased because of a new festival every weekend.
answerOptions.rationale: No events are mentioned; the budget cut better explains the decline.

answerOptions.text: The city plans to close all parks permanently.
answerOptions.rationale: The proposal focuses on upkeep, not closure.

questions.passage: A restaurant posted 'Now Hiring—Servers' next to a sign that read 'Please be patient—short staffed.' Customers waited twenty minutes to be seated at half-empty tables.
questions.question: What inference best explains the wait?

answerOptions.text: A staffing shortage limits how many tables can be served at once.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The signs and the half-empty dining room point to insufficient staff, not lack of space.

answerOptions.text: The kitchen has been permanently closed.
answerOptions.rationale: The restaurant is operating but understaffed, not closed.

answerOptions.text: Customers prefer to eat outside instead.
answerOptions.rationale: Preference is not mentioned; staffing explains the wait.

answerOptions.text: There is a health inspection happening in the kitchen.
answerOptions.rationale: No inspection is mentioned; signs cite staffing.

questions.passage: The instructor moved the exam from Friday to Wednesday and posted a detailed study guide and extra practice problems.
questions.question: What is the most reasonable inference?

answerOptions.text: The timeline was accelerated, but support materials were provided to help students prepare.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Moving the date up with added resources suggests a faster schedule balanced with support.

answerOptions.text: The exam was canceled.
answerOptions.rationale: The exam still occurs, just earlier.

answerOptions.text: No preparation materials will be available.
answerOptions.rationale: Materials were posted; this contradicts the passage.

answerOptions.text: The course is ending immediately.
answerOptions.rationale: Only the exam date changed; no course cancellation is mentioned.

questions.passage: A notice in the apartment lobby reads: 'Water shutoff Tuesday 9–11 a.m. for pipe repairs.' That morning, several tenants can be seen carrying buckets and pitchers filled with water into their units.
questions.question: What can you infer about the tenants' actions?

answerOptions.text: They stored water in advance to use during the shutoff.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Bringing full containers in before the shutoff indicates preparation.

answerOptions.text: They plan to take long showers during the shutoff.
answerOptions.rationale: With no running water, long showers are not possible.

answerOptions.text: They are moving out that day.
answerOptions.rationale: There is no evidence of moving; the context is water repairs.

answerOptions.text: They are hosting a building-wide party.
answerOptions.rationale: Buckets and pitchers suggest basic needs, not a party.

questions.passage: The customer stood at the counter, arms crossed, tapping his foot. He had been waiting for ten minutes, and the employees behind the counter were laughing and talking, seemingly unaware of him.
questions.question: What can be inferred about the customer?

answerOptions.text: He is in a very good mood.
answerOptions.rationale: His body language (crossed arms, tapping foot) suggests the opposite.

answerOptions.text: He is annoyed by the poor service.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. His posture and the fact that he is being ignored while the employees chat suggest he is annoyed.

answerOptions.text: He is a new employee in training.
answerOptions.rationale: He is a customer waiting for service, not an employee.

answerOptions.text: He has a lot of time and is not in a hurry.
answerOptions.rationale: His impatience suggests he is in a hurry or at least values his time.

questions.passage: The old theater was a glorious ruin. Velvet ropes, once a rich crimson, were now a dusty pink. Gold leaf peeled from the ornate ceiling, and the stage was a dark, silent mouth. It was a place where memories of thunderous applause and standing ovations echoed in the silence.
questions.question: What is the author's tone toward the old theater?

answerOptions.text: Modern and minimalist
answerOptions.rationale: The tone is focused on age and decay, not modernism.

answerOptions.text: Nostalgic and melancholic
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The author describes the theater's faded glory with a sense of sadness and a deep appreciation for its past, which is a nostalgic and melancholic tone.

answerOptions.text: Angry and critical
answerOptions.rationale: The tone is one of sad reverence, not anger.

answerOptions.text: Humorous and lighthearted
answerOptions.rationale: There is nothing funny about the description of the decaying theater.

questions.passage: The company's new 'unlimited vacation' policy sounds generous, but it has a catch. Because the policy does not specify a set number of days off, there is no requirement for the company to pay out unused vacation time when an employee leaves. The policy, framed as a benefit, is also a clever way for the company to save a significant amount of money.
questions.question: What is the author's purpose in this passage?

answerOptions.text: To persuade employees to take more vacation.
answerOptions.rationale: The author is not encouraging employees, but rather critiquing the policy.

answerOptions.text: To reveal an unstated, negative financial consequence of a seemingly positive company policy.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The author's purpose is to look behind the positive framing of the policy to expose a hidden, negative financial aspect that benefits the company at the expense of the employee.

answerOptions.text: To celebrate the generosity of the company.
answerOptions.rationale: The author is criticizing the policy, not celebrating it.

answerOptions.text: To provide a neutral, factual description of the new vacation policy.
answerOptions.rationale: The author's tone is critical and analytical, not neutral. The use of 'catch' and 'clever way' shows a clear point of view.

questions.passage: A note on the elevator door reads, 'Out of service—maintenance in progress.' A steady stream of people uses the stairwell.
questions.question: What is the best inference?

answerOptions.text: The elevator is temporarily unavailable, so people must take the stairs.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The sign and observed behavior support this.

answerOptions.text: The building has banned elevator use permanently.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Maintenance in progress' indicates a temporary issue, not a ban.

answerOptions.text: The stairwell is closed.
answerOptions.rationale: People are using the stairs, so it is open.

answerOptions.text: All tenants have moved out.
answerOptions.rationale: There is no evidence of vacancy; people are present and moving.

questions.passage: On a ninety-degree afternoon, the ice cream shop's line stretches out the door and down the block.
questions.question: What is the most reasonable inference?

answerOptions.text: Hot weather is driving unusually high demand for cold treats.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The long line on a very hot day suggests heat-related demand.

answerOptions.text: The shop is giving away ice cream for free.
answerOptions.rationale: No free promotion is mentioned; weather explains the crowd.

answerOptions.text: The shop is about to close forever.
answerOptions.rationale: There's no evidence of a permanent closure.

answerOptions.text: Everyone in line works at the shop.
answerOptions.rationale: They are customers waiting, not employees.

questions.passage: A nonprofit's annual report states it 'diversified funding sources.' Charts show government grants fell from 55% to 25% of revenue, while corporate sponsorships rose from 10% to 40%. A new wing bears a corporation's name.
questions.question: Which inference is best supported?

answerOptions.text: The organization has shifted reliance away from government grants toward corporate sponsors.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The percentages and naming rights indicate a substantial shift to corporate funding.

answerOptions.text: Government funding increased dramatically.
answerOptions.rationale: It decreased from 55% to 25%.

answerOptions.text: The nonprofit eliminated all private donations.
answerOptions.rationale: No evidence suggests elimination; the report shows growth in sponsorships.

answerOptions.text: The corporation runs the nonprofit now.
answerOptions.rationale: Naming rights do not imply operational control.

questions.passage: An announcement on the platform reports a 'significant delay due to signal issues.' Commuters sigh, check ride-share apps, and some head toward the exit.
questions.question: What is the most reasonable inference about commuter behavior?

answerOptions.text: Some riders are seeking alternate transportation because of the delay.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Checking apps and leaving the platform indicates looking for alternatives.

answerOptions.text: The trains are arriving on time.
answerOptions.rationale: The announcement says there is a significant delay.

answerOptions.text: The station is closing permanently.
answerOptions.rationale: Only a delay is mentioned; no closure is implied.

answerOptions.text: Everyone plans to sleep on the platform.
answerOptions.rationale: Passengers are leaving to find other options, not staying overnight.

questions.passage: After two turnovers in a row, the coach pulls the point guard and speaks to them quietly on the sideline before sending them back in later.
questions.question: What is the best inference about the coach's action?

answerOptions.text: The coach benched the player briefly to correct mistakes before returning them to the game.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The sequence indicates quick discipline and coaching, not a permanent benching.

answerOptions.text: The player was ejected by the referee.
answerOptions.rationale: Ejections are not temporary and are done by officials, not coaches.

answerOptions.text: The player quit the team.
answerOptions.rationale: The player re-enters the game later, so they did not quit.

answerOptions.text: The coach is ignoring the player's performance.
answerOptions.rationale: The coach addressed the mistakes directly.

questions.passage: A university moves many lecture courses online, sells a large parking lot to a developer, and signs an agreement with a coworking company to host study spaces near transit.
questions.question: Which conclusion is best supported?

answerOptions.text: The university is reducing its physical footprint while shifting toward hybrid/online learning.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Selling parking and partnering off-site align with fewer on-campus activities and more online delivery.

answerOptions.text: The university plans to build more on-campus parking.
answerOptions.rationale: They sold parking space, which suggests the opposite.

answerOptions.text: The university is eliminating all study spaces.
answerOptions.rationale: They are adding off-site study spaces, not eliminating them.

answerOptions.text: The university is banning online learning.
answerOptions.rationale: They are increasing, not banning, online courses.

questions.passage: The grocery store installed eight self-checkout kiosks and reduced the number of staffed lanes. Lines move faster, but there are fewer cashiers on duty.
questions.question: What inference best explains the change?

answerOptions.text: The store aims to increase checkout speed while lowering labor costs.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Installing kiosks and reducing staff points to efficiency and cost reduction goals.

answerOptions.text: The store plans to close permanently.
answerOptions.rationale: Investments in kiosks suggest continued operation, not closure.

answerOptions.text: The store will no longer accept credit cards.
answerOptions.rationale: Payment methods are not mentioned; kiosks typically accept cards.

answerOptions.text: Customers demanded longer checkout times.
answerOptions.rationale: The change produces shorter, not longer, lines.

questions.passage: A sign in the emergency room explains triage: 'Patients with life-threatening conditions are treated first.' The waiting room is crowded with people holding minor injuries.
questions.question: What inference can be made about wait times?

answerOptions.text: Patients with non-urgent issues will likely wait longer when severe cases arrive.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Triage prioritizes severity, increasing waits for minor cases during busy periods.

answerOptions.text: All patients are seen strictly in order of arrival.
answerOptions.rationale: Triage explicitly prioritizes severity, not arrival time alone.

answerOptions.text: Minor injuries will be treated immediately.
answerOptions.rationale: Immediate care is reserved for life-threatening cases under triage.

answerOptions.text: The ER is closed to new patients.
answerOptions.rationale: The room is crowded; there is no closure indicated.

questions.passage: A museum launches 'Pay What You Can Fridays.' Attendance on Fridays doubles, and donation boxes are placed near the entrance.
questions.question: Which inference is most supported by these details?

answerOptions.text: Lowering the cost barrier increased attendance on Fridays.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Attendance doubling after the policy change indicates reduced cost boosted visits.

answerOptions.text: The museum now charges more than before on Fridays.
answerOptions.rationale: The policy reduces required payment, not increases it.

answerOptions.text: Visitors are required to donate a fixed amount.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Pay what you can' is not a fixed requirement; donation boxes suggest optional giving.

answerOptions.text: The museum is closed on Fridays.
answerOptions.rationale: Attendance increased, meaning it's open and busier.

questions.passage: To ensure a safe and productive work environment, all employees are required to complete a new safety training module by the end of the month. This mandatory online course will cover updated emergency procedures, hazard communication, and the proper use of personal protective equipment. You can access the module through the employee portal. Failure to complete the training by the deadline may result in a temporary suspension of network access.
questions.question: Which sentence best states the main idea of the passage?

answerOptions.text: The company is introducing a new employee portal for better communication.
answerOptions.rationale: The portal is mentioned as a tool to access the training, but it is not the main topic.

answerOptions.text: All employees must complete a new, mandatory safety training module by the end of the month.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence accurately summarizes the central point of the workplace memo.

answerOptions.text: Employees who fail to complete the training will have their network access suspended.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a supporting detail about the consequences, not the main idea itself.

answerOptions.text: The training will cover emergency procedures and hazard communication.
answerOptions.rationale: This describes the content of the training, which is a detail supporting the main idea.

questions.passage: The city has launched a new recycling program to reduce landfill waste. Residents will receive a new blue bin for plastics, glass, and metals. Pick-up will be every two weeks on the same day as regular trash collection. A detailed guide of acceptable materials will be mailed to all households. The goal is to increase our recycling rate by 30% over the next year.
questions.question: What is the central message of this announcement?

answerOptions.text: The city is launching a new recycling program with blue bins and bi-weekly pick-up to reduce waste.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This statement captures the key components of the new program announced in the passage.

answerOptions.text: Residents will be mailed a detailed guide about acceptable materials.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a specific detail about how information will be shared, not the main idea.

answerOptions.text: The city wants to increase its recycling rate by 30%.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the goal of the program, a key detail, but not the entire main idea.

answerOptions.text: Pick-up for the new program will be on the same day as trash collection.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a logistical detail, not the central message.

questions.passage: Regular physical activity is crucial for maintaining good health. It strengthens the cardiovascular system, helps manage weight, and can improve mental clarity. Even moderate exercise, like a brisk 30-minute walk each day, can have significant long-term benefits. It is important to find an activity you enjoy to ensure you stick with it.
questions.question: Which sentence best expresses the main idea?

answerOptions.text: A 30-minute walk is a form of moderate exercise.
answerOptions.rationale: This is an example provided in the text, not the overall point.

answerOptions.text: You should find an enjoyable form of exercise.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a concluding tip, but not the main idea of the entire passage.

answerOptions.text: Regular physical activity is essential for good physical and mental health.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence summarizes the overall argument and its supporting points.

answerOptions.text: Exercise helps with weight management.
answerOptions.rationale: This is one of the specific benefits mentioned, not the central claim.

questions.passage: Before assembling your new bookshelf, please check that all parts are included. The package should contain four shelves, two side panels, one back panel, and a hardware kit with screws and a small wrench. If any items are missing, do not proceed with assembly. Instead, call our customer service number to request replacement parts.
questions.question: What is the main point of these instructions?

answerOptions.text: You should call customer service if you have questions.
answerOptions.rationale: This is what to do if parts are missing, not the main instruction.

answerOptions.text: Verify that you have all the necessary parts before you begin assembling the bookshelf.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The entire passage is focused on the preliminary step of checking for all components.

answerOptions.text: The bookshelf has four shelves and two side panels.
answerOptions.rationale: This lists some of the parts, but it is a detail, not the main directive.

answerOptions.text: Do not proceed with assembly if items are missing.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a key instruction, but it's part of the broader main idea of checking parts first.

questions.passage: Community gardens are becoming increasingly popular in urban areas. These shared plots of land offer residents a space to grow their own fresh produce, which can improve nutrition and reduce food costs. They also serve as valuable green spaces that foster social interaction and strengthen community bonds. Working together on a garden can help neighbors build relationships and create a shared sense of accomplishment.
questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?

answerOptions.text: Community gardens help people save money on groceries.
answerOptions.rationale: This is one of the benefits mentioned, but not the only one. The main idea is broader.

answerOptions.text: Working in a garden helps build a sense of accomplishment.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a social benefit, but not the complete central idea.

answerOptions.text: Community gardens provide multiple benefits to urban residents, including better nutrition and stronger social connections.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This statement encompasses both the practical (food) and social (community) benefits described.

answerOptions.text: Urban areas need more green spaces for social interaction.
answerOptions.rationale: While true according to the passage, the main idea is specifically about the role of community gardens.

questions.passage: The modern workplace is undergoing a significant transformation due to automation. While some fear that robots and artificial intelligence will eliminate jobs, others argue that these technologies will create new roles that require different skills. Repetitive, manual tasks are the most likely to be automated, allowing human workers to focus on complex problem-solving, creativity, and strategic thinking. The key to navigating this shift will be a commitment to lifelong learning and retraining.
questions.question: Which sentence best captures the central argument of the passage?

answerOptions.text: Robots and artificial intelligence are going to eliminate a large number of jobs in the future.
answerOptions.rationale: The passage presents this as one viewpoint but contrasts it with another, making this statement incomplete.

answerOptions.text: Workers should focus on developing skills in creativity and strategic thinking.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a key detail, but it doesn't encompass the entire argument about the transformation.

answerOptions.text: The automation of the workplace is shifting the focus of human jobs toward complex skills and requires continuous learning.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence summarizes the cause (automation), the effect (shift in job focus), and the solution (lifelong learning).

answerOptions.text: Repetitive, manual tasks are the first that will be automated in the workplace.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a specific point supporting the larger argument about the changing nature of work.

questions.passage: Financial literacy is a critical skill that is often overlooked in formal education. Understanding concepts like budgeting, saving, and investing is essential for long-term financial stability. Without this knowledge, individuals are more susceptible to debt and poor financial decisions. Several nonprofit organizations have begun offering free workshops to help adults build these necessary skills and take control of their economic futures.
questions.question: What is the main idea the author is conveying?

answerOptions.text: Nonprofit organizations are now offering free financial workshops.
answerOptions.rationale: This is presented as a solution, but the main idea is about the importance of the skill itself.

answerOptions.text: Financial literacy, which is crucial for stability, is an often-neglected skill that some organizations are now trying to teach.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This statement covers the importance of the skill, the problem (it's overlooked), and the emerging solution.

answerOptions.text: A lack of financial knowledge can lead to debt and other problems.
answerOptions.rationale: This explains the consequences of the problem, but it's not the entire main idea.

answerOptions.text: Budgeting, saving, and investing are key financial concepts.
answerOptions.rationale: These are examples of what financial literacy includes, not the central message about its importance.

questions.passage: Public speaking is a common source of anxiety, but it is a skill that can be developed with practice. Experts suggest starting with small, low-stakes situations, like speaking up in a team meeting. Preparing thoroughly and knowing your material can also significantly boost confidence. It is also helpful to remember that the audience is typically supportive and wants you to succeed.
questions.question: Which of the following best states the main idea of the passage?

answerOptions.text: Public speaking is a source of anxiety for many people.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the problem the passage addresses, but the main idea is about the solution.

answerOptions.text: Confidence is important for public speaking.
answerOptions.rationale: While true, the main idea is broader, explaining how to build that confidence.

answerOptions.text: Audiences are generally supportive of speakers.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a helpful tip mentioned in the passage, not its main point.

answerOptions.text: Anxiety about public speaking can be overcome through preparation and gradual practice.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence effectively summarizes the practical advice given in the passage.

questions.passage: The historical narrative of the American West often focuses on cowboys and settlers, but the reality was far more complex.
